content.description:
Read the following poem carefully before you choose your answers.

Katherine Philips’s poem “Friendship’s Mystery, To my Dearest Lucasia” was published in 1655.

Friendship’s Mystery, To my Dearest Lucasia

Come, my Lucasia, since we see

That Miracles Mens faith do move,

By wonder and by prodigy

To the dull angry1vexing, annoying world let’s prove

5            There’s a Religion in our Love.

For though we were design’d t’agree,

That Fate no liberty destroyes,

But our Election2exercise of choice is as free

As Angels, who with greedy3eager choice

10         Are yet determin’d to their joyes.

Our hearts are doubled by the loss,

Here Mixture is Addition grown;

We both diffuse, and both ingross:4absorb

And we whose minds are so much one,

15        Never, yet ever are alone.

We court our own Captivity

Than Thrones5name of a category of angels more great and innocent:

’Twere banishment to be set free,

Since we wear fetters whose intent

20       Not Bondage is, but Ornament.

Divided joyes are tedious found,

And griefs united easier grow:

We are our selves but by rebound,

And all our Titles shuffled so,

25       Both Princes, and both Subjects too.

Our Hearts are mutual Victims laid,

While they (such power in Friendship lies)

Are Altars, Priests, and Off’rings made:

And each Heart which thus kindly dies,

30      Grows deathless by the Sacrifice.
content.question: The speaker uses religious diction throughout the poem primarily to characterize friendship as

choices.label: a lasting reward for virtuous conduct
